author: By Gina Kolata

description: Zepbound, which is already sold by Eli Lilly as the diabetes treatment Mounjaro, was shown to reduce patients’ weight by as much as one-fifth in drug trials.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved an obesity drug from the company Eli Lilly that will be a direct competitor to the wildly popular Wegovy.

title: How One Small Statistic Became a Story That Spanned a Continent
description: Our chief Africa reporter was wary of journalism that made broad predictions about the continent, but a statistic made clear that staggering change was approaching.
content: The two-story house in Nairobi, Kenya that New York Times journalists have been renting since the early 2000s had some notable features when my family moved in three years ago: banana, guava and avocado trees; a thatched, mud-walled hut in the garden, built by a previous Times reporter; and a small library of books about Africa amassed over several decades.

title: Workers Making Clothes for Top Brands Reject a Proposal: $113 a Month

content: Days after violent protests over wages as low as $80 a month, officials in Bangladesh said on Wednesday they would increase the pay of garment workers by about 50 percent, a concession that appeared to fall short of satisfying thousands of workers who produce clothes for brands like H&M and Zara.

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Ukraine Gets an Encouraging Sign in Its Bid to Join the E.U.
description: The European Union’s executive arm recommended beginning membership talks with Ukraine on condition of some further changes in Kyiv.
content: The European Union’s executive arm recommended on Wednesday that the bloc open membership talks with Ukraine, an encouraging step for the government in Kyiv in what remains a long and arduous joining process.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Big Day for the House of Mouse
description: Investors, including the activist Nelson Peltz, are awaiting an earnings report from Disney — and updates on potential deals, cost cuts and more.
content: On Wednesday, Bob Iger will deliver one of the most consequential earnings reports for Disney since returning as C.E.O. almost a year ago. He has had to confront many problems, including a slumping share price, strikes that have crippled much of Hollywood, the wrenching transformations wrought by streaming and renewed pressure from the activist investor Nelson Peltz.

content: Representative Mike Johnson wasn’t the first — or second — choice for speaker of the House, but he was the only congressman to successfully secure a majority of votes. He now faces his first major test with a deadline looming for a government shutdown on Nov. 17.

title: Minnesota Justices Rebuff Attempt to Bar Trump From Ballot Under 14th Amendment

content: The Minnesota Supreme Court on Wednesday dismissed a petition seeking to disqualify former President Donald J. Trump from holding office again under the 14th Amendment.

author: By Bret Stephens
title: For America’s Jews, Every Day Must Be Oct. 8
description: We got our wake-up call the day after the massacre. It’s time to act.
content: There used to be a sign (which, for all I know, is still there) somewhere in the C.I.A.’s headquarters that read, “Every day is Sept. 12.” It was placed there to remind the agency’s staffers that what they felt right after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001 — the sense of outrage and purpose, of favoring initiative over caution, of taking nothing for granted — had to be the mind-set with which they arrived to work every day.

title: Mayor Adams Denies Wrongdoing and Retains Lawyer After Federal Raid
description: In his first open media availability since agents raided his chief fund-raiser’s home, Eric Adams insisted he often reminds his team, “We’ve got to follow the law.”

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘What’s Cooking in the Kremlin’? A Heady Mix of Propaganda and Paranoia.
description: The new book by Witold Szablowski features the chefs who were expected to prepare sumptuous meals for Russian leaders — and keep them from being poisoned.
content: Witold Szablowski describes a number of surprising dishes in his entertaining yet unnerving new book, “What’s Cooking in the Kremlin,” which explores the last century of Russian history through its food. But none is as surreal as the recipe for one of Lenin’s favorites. The instructions for making his “scrambled eggs using three eggs” orders you to break the eggs but not to beat them. What Lenin called “scrambled eggs” were actually fried eggs, with their yolks and whites intact — not scrambled at all.

author: By Rick Rojas and Jessica Jaglois

description: Even with a perceived likability problem and a Democratic opponent who out-raised him, Mr. Reeves won re-election as governor by a comfortable margin.
content: National Democratic groups routed millions of dollars into Mississippi, sensing that Tate Reeves, the Republican governor, might be vulnerable. content: The Chinese leader Xi Jinping, who is set to meet with President Biden in San Francisco next week, is expected to speak to top American business executives at a dinner following that bilateral meeting.

title: Abortion Rights Fuel Big Democratic Wins, and Hopes for 2024

content: Democrats won decisive victories in major races across the country on Tuesday evening, overcoming the downward pull of an unpopular president, lingering inflation and growing global unrest by relying on abortion, the issue that has emerged as their fail-safe since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year.

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Hoexter’s, With Deep Ties to the Upper East Side, Returns With a Refresh
description: Levantine fare at Huda, a Lightscape Lodge at Brooklyn Botanic Garden and more restaurant news.
content: Back in the 1970s and ’80s, the Upper East Side was a dining destination. Summon memories, if you can, of the Sign of the Dove, Parioli Romanissimo, Mortimer’s, Elaine’s, David K, Quo Vadis, Le Cirque, Jams, Arcadia, An American Place and many more. On the list was a chop house, Hoexter’s Market (two stars from Mimi Sheraton in The New York Times in 1978). It was an adjunct to a butcher shop, also called Hoexter’s Market, both owned by Robert Shapiro who went on to open Flex Mussels in more than one location. Hoexter’s Market, with a checker logo (as in checker cabs, another memory) closed in the mid-80s. But recently, Alexandra Shapiro, a daughter of Mr. Shapiro, and Laura Shapiro, his wife, have been determined to revive Hoexter’s. “It’s been my mission,” Alexandra said. And the family has done it.  Steps from the original location, it has dropped the Market from the name. Enter into the bar, forest green with fanciful wallpaper, then proceed to the main dining room with rough brick and plaid on the walls, tablecloths and a mural showing regulars from the original restaurant. Another dining room beyond has a shimmering chandelier, red leather banquettes and a celestial theme, and doubles as a party space. The chef, Lauren Schwichtenberg, has roots in Oklahoma and Minnesota, and her menu is as contemporary as its double smash cheeseburger. Also on offer are tuna crudo, onion soup, steamed artichoke, chopped salad, pork Milanese, a roast chicken, Faroe Island salmon with smoked beurre blanc and prime rib for two. (Opens Saturday)

title: Tens of Thousands Flee Northern Gaza Strip, as Israel’s Invasion Advances
description: The United Nations estimated that 15,000 civilians walked out of northern Gaza on Tuesday, three times as many as the day before, while Israeli troops battled Hamas in Gaza City.
content: Tens of thousands of desperate civilians, some waving white flags, have fled the northern Gaza Strip this week, marching along a road pocked with airstrike craters and lined with ruined buildings, as Israeli officials reported that their troops had pushed into the heart of the densely populated Hamas stronghold of Gaza City.

title: Can’t Make the Concert? Livestreamers Are Coming to the Rescue.

author: By Michael Snyder and Ana Topoleanu
title: Wacky, Curvaceous Houses in Brazil That Feel Like Cocoons
description: How a handful of organic 20th-century homes by the architect Jorge Zalszupin came to redefine Modernist design.
content: THE POLISH BRAZILIAN designer and architect Jorge Zalszupin hated the beach, but he loved the beach house he built in 1972 for his family. Set back from the Atlantic coast in Guarujá, a resort town 40 miles southeast of São Paulo, the 2,842-square-foot white concrete dwelling looks like a block of bleached coral pulled from the ocean. The front door opens onto a spiral staircase that leads to a pair of bedrooms and a lofted lounge; below, the walls of a sunken living room curve up to a sculptural ceiling. A built-in couch wraps around a bell-shaped fireplace, its crescent hearth like an open mouth. Shielded from the Brazilian sun that his wife, a homemaker named Annette, and two daughters adored, Zalszupin would spend entire weekends listening to Chet Baker and Brahms, bent over mounds of clay that he formed into models for chairs and sofas — the furniture that had won him acclaim by the end of the 1950s — and for houses that were, until recently, far less known.

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Blinken Lays Out Possible Endgame in Gaza Under Palestinian Authority
description: The secretary of state said Gaza should be overseen by the Palestinian Authority, which has a tenuous hold on power in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said Wednesday that Gaza should be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority once the war is over, offering a strong signal about what the United States sees as its preferred endgame in the fight between Israel and Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: A Package of Bold Laws Puts Michigan on a Fast Track to Renewable Energy
description: Included in the new legislation is a requirement that the state generate all of its electricity from wind, solar and other carbon-free sources by 2040.
content: The Michigan Senate gave final approval on Wednesday to a bundle of clean energy bills, transforming a state at the center of industrial America into a leader in the fight against climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Republicans Subpoena Biden’s Son and Brother in Impeachment Inquiry
description: Representative James Comer, the chairman of the Oversight Committee, demanded testimony from James Biden and Hunter Biden as he hunts for evidence of bribery and corruption by the president.
content: House Republicans on Wednesday issued subpoenas demanding testimony from Hunter and James Biden, the president’s son and brother, as they hunt for evidence to try to build an impeachment case against him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Nicholas Fandos
title: Ending 40-Year Hiatus, G.O.P. Wins a City Council Seat in the Bronx
description: Although Democrats won contentious races all across New York, losses in the Bronx and throughout Long Island gave Republicans hope.
content: The last time voters in the Bronx were represented by a Republican on the City Council, Mayor Ed Koch was still asking voters “How’m I doin’,” Ronald Reagan was president and hip-hop music was mostly a local phenomenon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: What Voters Want That Trump Seems to Have
description: Voters could end up seeing the ex-president as the nostalgia candidate, the change candidate and the protest candidate all in one.
content: So about that poll. You know the one: the Times/Siena poll showing Donald Trump with an edge over President Biden in five out of six swing states, and suggesting a softening of support for Mr. Biden among Black, Latino and young voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: N.J. Democrats Retain Legislative Majority After Hard-Fought Races
description: Democrats won in competitive districts in southern, central and northern New Jersey.
content: Democrats in New Jersey retained a comfortable majority in the General Assembly and the State Senate in Tuesday’s legislative races.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly White
title: Sam Bankman-Fried and the People Who Gave Up Their Money for Nothing
description: Vast swaths of the cryptocurrency industry, including FTX, are propped up by pumping up the price of a token with no real value behind it.
content: Speaking at his criminal trial, looking visibly uncomfortable in an ill-fitting gray suit, Sam Bankman-Fried recounted a “screw-up” in which he was outwitted by a trader who had gotten around $800 million out of his company FTX. Mr. Bankman-Fried had Alameda Research, his ostensibly separate trading arm, take over the hugely negative account, thus — according to at least one witness — hiding the loss from FTX’s investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Tales That Crackle With Vitality, With or Without a Puppeteer
description: La MaMa Puppet Festival and other stage works this fall highlight the power of storytelling through puppetry.
content: In a crisp white gallery space on Great Jones Street, in Manhattan’s East Village, a large wooden box contains a meticulous mise-en-scène: a midcentury roadside motel room constructed at puppet scale, which means it’s half of human scale. Standing on a step built into the outside of the box, spectators can gaze down into the installation, a time-capsule environment called “Motel,” by the master puppet artist Dan Hurlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Mass Grave Recalls the Ugly Past of a City Where ‘Life Is Sweeter’
description: The Houston suburb Sugar Land got its name from a business reliant on the forced labor of convicts. But efforts to memorialize those people have stalled.
content: In Sugar Land, Texas, there’s a refrain you may hear from residents — an unofficial city motto of sorts: Life is sweeter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: extrapolate
description: This word has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word extrapolate has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 27 in “‘The Beanie Bubble’ Review: Caught in a Fad Romance” by Calum Marsh:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Tuesday Was Great for Democrats. It Doesn’t Change the Outlook for 2024.
description: A pattern continued with success in low-turnout elections, which favors highly engaged voters. Presidential years tend to be different.
content: Almost every Tuesday election since the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has brought good news for Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Wins for Abortion Rights in 3 States, and More
description: Plus, a House censure for Representative Rashida Tlaib and an expansion in fossil fuel extraction.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: A Gaza ‘Cease-Fire’ or a ‘Pause’? Even World Leaders Are Confused.
description: Experts say neither term is defined under international law.
content: Pause, or cease-fire?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Riley-Adams
title: Slowly and Steadily, Snails Have Overtaken the Runway
description: In an era of expediency, gastropods are oozing into fashion and design — and reminding us that we, too, can take our time.
content: In September, at Prada’s spring 2024 women’s show, models walked between translucent curtains of pink slime that dripped from the ceiling and pooled on the floor. The brand referred to them as “fluid interruptions,” a concept that was echoed in the collection’s flowing organza dresses and fringed skirts. Above all, though, it evoked the secretions of a snail, an animal that has recently been crawling into the realms of design and fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Nations That Vowed to Halt Warming Are Expanding Fossil Fuels, Report Finds
description: The world remains on track to produce far more oil, gas and coal than would be consistent with relatively safe levels of heating, a new report found.
content: In 2030, if current projections hold, the United States will drill for more oil and gas than at any point in its history. Russia and Saudi Arabia plan to do the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Behind Hamas’s Bloody Gambit to Create a ‘Permanent’ State of War
description: Hamas leaders say they waged their Oct. 7 attack on Israel because they believed the Palestinian cause was slipping away, and that only violence could revive it.
content: Thousands have been killed in Gaza, with entire families wiped out. Israeli airstrikes have reduced Palestinian neighborhoods to expanses of rubble, while doctors treat screaming children in darkened hospitals with no anesthesia. Across the Middle East, fear has spread over the possible outbreak of a broader regional war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Democrats Won Big in Last Night’s Elections
description: Also, the F.D.A. approved a new obesity drug. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Abortion rights and marijuana legalization prevailed in Ohio. Democrats held the governor’s mansion in Kentucky, took full control of the General Assembly in Virginia and won a Supreme Court election in Pennsylvania. They were even competitive in Mississippi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Print Specification
description: Daniel Hrynick makes his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Virginia Dashes Youngkin’s Hopes of a G.O.P. Takeover, and Maybe More
description: Democratic victories in the state’s legislative races delivered a major setback to the Republican governor, who is widely seen as eyeing the presidency.
content: For months, some of the Republican Party’s top donors have dreamed of a dramatic late entrance into the presidential race by Gov. Glenn Youngkin of Virginia, envisioning an improbable scenario in which the fleece-vested former financier rips control of the party away from Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Nikki Haley’s Rise Could Turn the Republican Nomination Race Brutal
description: Win or lose, Nikki Haley knows how to run.
content: A long time ago in South Carolina, as Nikki Haley recalls when she talks to voters in New Hampshire and Iowa, she ran campaigns that nobody thought much of until, unexpectedly, suddenly, she was winning them. Is that what’s happening here? Is this real?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: U.S. Strikes Iran-Linked Facility in Syria in Round of Retaliation
description: Drone and rocket attacks on U.S. forces have continued in recent weeks, prompting a second round of retaliatory airstrikes in eastern Syria.
content: For the second time in nearly two weeks, the United States carried out airstrikes against a facility used by Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and its proxies in eastern Syria early Thursday, ratcheting up retaliation for a steady stream of rocket and drone attacks against American forces in Iraq and Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My 75-Year-Old Husband Wants Sex Every Day. What Do I Do?
description: A reader feels frustrated by her husband’s daily expectations of sex, which she worries may be a sign of something more troubling.
content: I am 55, and my husband is 75. We’ve been married for 25 years. He is retired and keeps himself busy while I am at work. Lately, he waits for me every day — with bated breath — so we can have sex when I get home. He complains that I can’t keep up with him sexually. But I need some me time: He doesn’t consider that I work full time, have a lengthy commute and still have to make dinner. I can’t talk to my friends about this; they would think I was crazy. Should I have him checked by a doctor? Is he suffering from early dementia? I love him, but he is wearing me out. Would I be better off without him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: In Bridgeport, the Mayoral Election Isn’t Over Until It’s Over
description: The mayor was re-elected, but another vote may take place after a judge voided the Democratic primary results because of credible allegations of ballot fraud.
content: Mayor Joe Ganim of Bridgeport, Conn., was the top vote-getter in his bid for re-election on Tuesday, beating his closest opponent by 175 votes. Ordinarily that would guarantee him another term in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Germans Recoil at Push to Rename ‘Anne Frank’ Day Care
description: The proposed change, reportedly at the behest of parents and employees who found her story difficult to explain to children, comes amid acute concern about rising antisemitism in Germany.
content: A proposal in a small German town to rename a public day care center that is currently named after Anne Frank has become the center of a fraught national debate in the country about antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $800,000 Homes in Rhode Island, Oregon and Ohio
description: An early 19th-century house in North Kingstown, a two-bedroom condominium in Portland and an English country-style home in Upper Arlington.
content: This house, built for Esbon Sanford, a local factory owner, has been sensitively updated, with much of its original character retained, and it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is about a five-minute drive from North Kingstown Town Beach and from John H. Chafee Nature Preserve, where walking trails lead to a rocky expanse of waterfront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Lucky Find at Auction Identifies Man on Cover of ‘Led Zeppelin IV’
description: It’s not a painting. It’s a picture of a Victorian artisan taken in the English countryside in 1892.
content: On Nov. 8, 1971, Led Zeppelin released its iconic fourth studio album, which was untitled but is widely known as “Led Zeppelin IV.” It features the band’s major hit “Stairway to Heaven,” and the wordless cover shows the image of a bearded, older man with a large bundle of sticks on his back against the backdrop of a decaying wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: ‘The Longer and Bloodier the War, the Harder it Will Be for the Democratic Coalition’
description: The war between Israel and Hamas could splinter the Biden electorate.
content: The Hamas terrorist attacks on Israel and Israel’s retaliatory strikes on Gaza are creating a fissure between Democratic constituencies crucial to President Biden’s campaign for a second term in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: Leave It to Beavers? Not if You’re a Wolf.
description: This is what happens when an apex predator collides with an ecosystem engineer.
content: Beavers are influential. By cutting trees and damming streams, these rodents change the world around them, raising water levels and creating habitats for diverse plants, insects, fish and more. They are some of the world’s best-known ecosystem engineers, a term for species that produce outsize effects on their environments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Eagle and Ropes
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Her Retirement Home Said ‘No’ to Solar Panels. She Got It to Buy 1,344.
description: In what seemed like a futile fight with her retirement community’s management, Susan Auslander, just shy of 90, found an opening.
content: Susan Auslander, at 89, is an energetic, convent-educated, white-haired Prius driver, and when her retirement community told her it was not feasible to convert to solar power, Ms. Auslander decided to push back. That push turned into a a five-year campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: How Are Students Expected to Live Like This on Campuses?
description: As a principle of academic debate, speech should be presumptively allowed. The details of achieving that may get messy, but that goal is fundamental.
content: It was a relief to learn of the arrest last week of a 21-year-old Cornell University student for threatening to rape and murder Jews on campus in reaction to the Israel-Hamas war. It was also an easy case: Violent threats against specific people are illegal, and they are dealt with by the justice system, not school administrators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Does the Boss Need to Weigh In on the War in the Middle East?
description: It’s become the norm for company executives to issue notes to employees about social upheaval. But the Israel-Hamas war presents a special challenge.
content: After reading the details of Hamas’s attacks on Israel on Oct. 7, Brad Karp, who runs the law firm Paul, Weiss, sat at his computer and wrote a memo to his roughly 2,000 employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: ‘Mean Girls’ Adaptation Trailer Inspires Mixed Reactions
description: Ahead of the release of the film adaptation of the “Mean Girls” musical, some fans said the new spin on the classic 2004 movie had a lot to live up to. Others said they felt old.
content: Paramount Pictures on Wednesday released a trailer for the film adaptation of the Broadway musical “Mean Girls,” which was itself an adaptation of the beloved 2004 movie about a girl trying to fit in with the popular crowd at her high school. The new film is due to hit theaters on Jan. 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France Links Conversation in Russian to Star of David Graffiti
description: After more than 200 blue stars were stenciled on buildings in and around Paris, prosecutors say they are investigating whether a foreign intermediary paid a couple to spray paint them.
content: French prosecutors are investigating whether a foreign intermediary was behind the painting of more than 200 blue Stars of David on buildings in and around Paris last month amid a surge of antisemitic acts in Europe since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Gabe Amo Is Elected Rhode Island’s First Black Member of Congress
description: Mr. Amo, Democrat and the son of West African immigrants, served in the Biden and Obama administrations.
content: Gabe Amo, a former White House staff member who worked in the Biden and Obama administrations, on Tuesday became the first Black person to represent Rhode Island in the U.S. Congress, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: As Israel Pushes Deeper Into Northern Gaza, Thousands Trek South
description: The United Nations estimates that 15,000 people used the only route out of the northern part of the enclave on Tuesday, three times the number that passed the day before.
content: Pocked with airstrike craters and lined by Israeli tanks and the shells of what used to be buildings, Salah al-Din Road is the only way to leave the northern part of Gaza for the south, where Israel has told civilians to go “for their own safety.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Thursday Briefing: What’s Next in the Israel-Hamas War
description: Plus, a cook’s tour of the Tokyo food scene.
content: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said yesterday that Gaza should be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority once the war ends, the strongest signal yet from the Biden administration about what it would like to see at the end of Israel’s fight against Hamas. But what Israel will do in Gaza is largely unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: Amid Criticism, a Museum Says It Must Sell Its Cézannes to Survive
description: Critics say it is violating industry guidelines by selling the works, but the Museum Langmatt in Switzerland said it must do so to avoid insolvency.
content: When a Swiss museum announced in September that it would be putting three paintings by Paul Cézanne, the Impressionist master, up for sale at auction, there was immediate protest by some who suggested the sale violated ethical guidelines on when institutions should sell off their works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Elizabeth Moynihan, Engine of the Senator’s Success, Dies at 94
description: She not only had an outsize role in New York and Washington politics as the wife of Daniel Patrick Moynihan; she also made a significant archaeological discovery in India.
content: Elizabeth Moynihan, who was a vital political partner to her husband, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, during his four terms as a U.S. Senator from New York; played a consequential role in Washington herself; and, as an architectural historian, made a signal discovery in India, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Deadly Strike on Civilian Ship at Black Sea Port
description: The episode, which killed one and injured four others, comes amid a recent uptick in military activity and attacks in the Black Sea, a hot spot in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
content: Ukraine said on Wednesday that a Russian missile had struck a civilian ship while it was moored in a port in the Black Sea region of Odesa, killing a port pilot on board and injuring three crew members and a port worker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Former C.I.A. Officer Pleads Guilty to Sexual Abuse Charges
description: The former officer, Brian Jeffrey Raymond, 47, admitted that he had sexually assaulted dozens of women, dating back as far as 2006, both in the United States and overseas, federal prosecutors said.
content: A former C.I.A. officer who worked at the American Embassy in Mexico City pleaded guilty on Tuesday to drugging and sexually assaulting more than two dozen women over a period of 14 years, the Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Why Voters Are So Down on the Biden Economy
description: Economists and voters often talk past each other. That doesn’t make voters wrong.
content: Economists, meet Sara. She is in her early 50s, white, an office manager who lives in South Carolina and a Republican who is unenthusiastic about Donald Trump. When she thinks about the direction of the country right now, what she’s most worried about is the economy. And whom does she blame for the economy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: What We Learned From Barbra Streisand’s Memoir
description: “My Name Is Barbra,” her long-awaited (and rather enormous) autobiography, doesn’t have an index. But here are the best bits.
content: “Looking back, it was much more fun to dream of being famous than to actually be famous,” Barbra Streisand writes near the end of “My Name Is Barbra,” her new memoir. “I didn’t like all the ridiculous stories they made up, or the envy my success provoked.” Here, culled from the book’s 970 pages, is her version of a very examined life, replete with triumphs and slights, love affairs and famous friends, anxiety and antiques and (always) food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Mental Illness, Especially Later in Life, Can Increase the Risk of Dementia
description: Research is revealing an inextricable link between mental disorders and neurological disorders.
content: In 2021, Sharon Niederhaus, then 77, lost her husband of more than 50 years. Her daughter, Kristin Henry, said her mother was never the same afterward. “We feel like we lost both our parents at the same time,” Ms. Henry said, referring to her and her brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Are We Finally Ready for a Male Contraceptive?
description: A fascinating set of birth control innovations is in development.
content: In last Wednesday’s newsletter, I wrote about the side effects that some women experience with various hormonal birth control methods, as well as with nonhormonal implants like the copper IUD. I believe those side effects need to be more fully discussed by more medical professionals so that young women in particular don’t get stuck with incomplete or potentially incorrect information from snake oil salesmen on social media pushing less effective birth control methods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The New York Times Passes 10 Million Subscribers
description: The company reported an adjusted operating profit of $89.8 million in its latest quarter, up from $69 million a year earlier.
content: The New York Times now has more than 10 million subscribers, the company said on Wednesday, edging closer to its goal of 15 million by the end of 2027.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, David Bolaños and Daniele Volpe
title: A New Answer for Migrants in Central America: Bus Them North
description: Costa Rica and Panama are busing people through their countries to ease the concentration of people along their borders, which Biden officials fear will encourage more people to travel to the U.S. border.
content: Miranda Villasmil guided her daughter and son past hundreds of huddled migrants, many still muddied and swollen from their trek here to Costa Rica from South America. The family of three carried just two grocery bags of their belongings from their past lives in Venezuela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: France’s Justice Minister Goes on Trial, Accused of Abusing His Power
description: The case is the first time a sitting government minister has gone before a court, and it is part of the system he continues to oversee.
content: Even in France, where political corruption cases abound, it was a sight to behold: the country’s justice minister standing alone before two rows of judges in an ancient, wood-paneled courtroom to defend himself over accusations about his own use — or abuse — of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: ‘If Not Me, Who?’: As Ukraine Seeks Troops, Women Prepare for the Call
description: With so much in the war against Russia hinging on refilling the ranks of soldiers, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army.
content: Halyna Vynokur, a clerk in a hardware store in Kyiv, was shouldering a firearm for the first time. Iryna Sychova, a purchasing manager at a department store, disassembled and reassembled the jumble of rods and springs in a Kalashnikov rifle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Michigan Democrats Win 2 Mayoral Races but Lose Full Command of State Government
description: The shift is likely to only be temporary, but control of Michigan’s House will be evenly divided after two members resign to become suburban mayors.
content: Ten months ago, Michigan Democrats took full control of state government for the first time in 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Diana Nguyen, Olivia Natt, Rachel Quester, Brendan Klinkenberg, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Trumps Take the Stand
description: Former President Donald J. Trump and some of his children have given testimony in his civil fraud trial in Manhattan.
content: Of all the legal cases that former President Donald J. Trump is facing, perhaps the most personal is playing out in a courtroom in Manhattan: a civil fraud trial that could result in him losing control of his best-known buildings and paying hundreds of millions of dollars in fines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon Pokes Fun at the Republican Debate’s Lackluster Lineup
description: Fallon joked that “tomorrow at 9 p.m., CBS has ‘The Amazing Race,’ and NBC has the opposite.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Gen Alpha Is Here. Can You Understand Their Slang?
description: Are you a “sigma”? Do you have “rizz”? The youngest generation is bamboozling its elders with terms all their own.
content: Do you know what a gyat is? What about a rizzler? And how, precisely, does one pay a Fanum tax?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Levy
title: The Road Back From Hell
description: Nations that have come out against a cease-fire may think they are cheering Israel on to a righteous victory, but Israel’s current course only ensures its perpetual instability.
content: Each day the Israel-Gaza war continues, the risks of a cataclysm intensify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Race for Houston Mayor Heads to a Runoff
description: In a field of more than a dozen candidates, two well-known Texas Democrats emerged: U.S. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee and State Senator John Whitmire.
content: The race to become Houston’s mayor is heading for a runoff between two longtime Texas Democrats: United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee and a veteran state senator, John Whitmire, according to The Associated Press. Each emerged from a field of more than a dozen candidates on Tuesday, but neither with a majority of the vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The OA’ Creators Are Back With a Murder Mystery
description: “A Murder at the End of the World” resembles other luxe murder shows. But the mark of the creators, Brit Marling and Zal Batmanglij, is clear in its distinctive tone and themes.
content: The filmmakers Brit Marling and Zal Batmanglij have what they call a “garden.” It’s not an actual garden, however. It is what Batmanglij described in a recent interview as a “garden of ideas that exists between us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Godfather of Climate Science Turns Up the Heat
description: James Hansen says we must realize that we’ve underestimated how much the planet is warming.
content: It is, James Hansen says, worse than you think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Emily Cochrane
title: Andy Beshear, a Democrat, Defeats Daniel Cameron to Remain Kentucky Governor
description: The expensive and at times bitter contest was one of just three elections for governor this year, all in traditionally strong Republican states.
content: Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky won a second term on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, earning a noteworthy victory for a Democrat in a deeply conservative state and one that validated his pragmatic approach over a first term buffeted by a series of natural disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Vivek Ramaswamy Loves His Heritage. Just Don’t Call Him an Indian American.
description: The Republican presidential candidate says the celebration of diversity in America has come at the cost of national unity.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy does not shy away from his Indian heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 8, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 8, 2023.
content: An article on Saturday about a temporary lift of the gag order imposed on former President Donald J. Trump referred incorrectly to the duration that a gag order imposed on Mr. Trump will be paused. A federal appeals court in Washington set no timeline for the length of the pause; the court did not lift the gag order for about two weeks, though it did set a two-week timetable for the parties to file papers in Mr. Trump’s overarching appeal of the order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: A Dedicated Taylor Swift Reporter Faces Swift Criticism Online
description: Bryan West landed a much-coveted job. Then came the internet.
content: Everything has changed for Bryan West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller
title: Five Things Tom Dixon Wishes He’d Created
description: The designer, who’s debuting a line of portable lighting, looks to geodesic domes and bicycles.
content: “Fuller wasn’t a trained architect, but he was dreaming of the future. It still looks very modern now, especially compared to [contemporary] buildings.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Mother of Uvalde Shooting Victim Loses Mayor’s Race to Political Veteran
description: Cody Smith, who twice held the mayor’s post, defeated two other candidates, including Kimberly Mata-Rubio, whose daughter died in a mass shooting last year.
content: Kimberly Mata-Rubio, whose daughter was killed last year in a mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, lost a special election to become mayor of a city that has struggled with divisions in the aftermath of the tragedy, The Associated Press reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Citigroup Discriminated Against Armenian Americans, Regulator Says
description: The bank agreed to pay nearly $26 million to settle claims that its employees denied an immigrant community in Southern California fair access to its credit cards.
content: Citigroup employees labeled a group of roughly 80,000 Armenian Americans living near Los Angeles — the largest Armenian community outside Yerevan, the Armenian capital — as “bad guys” and secretly denied them fair access to the bank’s credit card products, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said in a statement on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni, Katherine Mangu-Ward and Nate Silver

content: Cecilia Aldarondo takes the process of reliving adolescent trauma to a literal degree in “You Were My First Boyfriend,” her feature that falls somewhere between documentary and diaristic re-enactment. Spurred by her 20-year high school reunion in Winter Park, Fla., Aldarondo pulls back layers of memories and old home-movie footage to investigate the significant relationships of her formative years: her first intense crush, her bullies, and her childhood best friend and fellow outsider, Caroline.

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: How Hermès Turned a Dog Collar Into a Bag
description: This cabochon-accented accessory nods to the brand’s animal-focused roots.
content: In 1821, a 20-year-old innkeeper’s son named Thierry Hermès, who grew up in the German textile town of Krefeld, moved to France’s Normandy region and apprenticed as a saddler. Eleven years later, he opened his own workshop in Paris, where he sold harnesses, bridles and saddles crafted with a stitch that can only be done by hand. After the advent of the automobile, Thierry’s grandson Émile-Maurice Hermès expanded the company’s offerings to include driving accessories and luggage trunks, as well as clocks and wristwatches with leather casings and straps. In 1923, the house even introduced a collection of dog collars, which were elaborately decorated with leather studs, metal looped rings and fringed trimmings. They became so popular that women began wearing them as belts; as the story goes, the French couturier Marie Callot Gerber, whose dogs wore the collars, commissioned Hermès to reinterpret them as wrist cuffs.

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Pasta and Rice May Be Healthier as Leftovers. Here’s Why.
description: Experts explain the resistant starch trend circulating on social media.
content: It sounds like just another internet health hack: Cook some pasta or white rice and let it cool overnight in the refrigerator. By the next day, some of the natural starches in the food will have transformed into healthier versions, called resistant starches, which have been linked to a range of health benefits including lower blood sugar, better gut health and a reduced risk of certain types of cancer.

author: By Zoey Poll
title: Paris’s Newest Hotels Embrace Color and Quirk
description: From the Marais to the Champs-Élysées, the French capital is suddenly full of small, exuberantly designed places to stay.
content: Until recently, few Parisian hotels dared to distract from the classic aesthetics of the city itself. The décor of its gilded palace hotels, single-minded embassies of French heritage, was, largely, fussy and excessively impersonal, as if a misplaced streak of color could break the city’s spell. Today the capital is finally overcoming its self-seriousness, thanks in part to its vibrant post-Brexit ascendancy in the contemporary arts and culture scenes. Many of its new hotels seek to delight rather than simply impress, and often conjure other worlds, as in the Marais’s Maison Proust, a candlelit Belle Époque fantasy half-hidden behind tasseled indigo velvet curtains, or the nearby Le Grand Mazarin, fashioned by the London-based Swedish designer Martin Brudnizki from contrasting styles and eras, all in a swirl of candy colors. “It took longer than New York and London,” says the Italian architect and designer Fabrizio Casiraghi, “but Paris is at last discovering the kind of small hotel that has something to say.”
